title: Homework
text:
Assignments are due by 11:59 PM via Gradescope (Entry Code: D684VR).
Read about how to submit assignments on Gradescope here. Some pointers:

title: Homework
text:
Late Day Policy
You will have a total of 6 late days to use on homework assignments with a maximum of 2 late days on a single assignment. Each late day can be treated as a 24-hr extension; e.g., if the assignment is due Wednesday at 11:59 pm, you may hand it in by Thursday at 11:59 pm and use one late day, or by Friday at 11:59 pm and use two late days. You are responsible for keeping track of your late days. No credit will be given for homework turned in after 48 hours past the due date, or for late homework after all late days have been used.

title: Homework
text:
Collaboration Policy and Honor Code
Students must work individually on all homework assignments. We encourage you to have high-level discussions with other students in the class about the assignments, however, we require that when you turn in an assignment, it is only your work. That is, copying any part of another student‚Äôs assignment is strictly prohibited. You are free to reuse small snippets of example code found on the Internet (e.g.¬†via StackOverflow) provided that it is attributed.

title: Homework
text:
Generative AI Tools Policy:
In this course, every element of class assignments must be fully prepared by the student. The use of generative AI tools for any part of your work is not allowed and will be treated as plagiarism ‚Äì unless it is permitted and announced by the instructor.

title: Homework
text:
Regrade Policy
You may submit a regrade request for homework on Gradescope. Please include a thorough description of the error that the grader made. You must submit a regrade request within 1 week of receiving your grade, by end of day (i.e.¬†11:59 pm). Some notes:

We reserve the right to regrade the entire assignment on a regrade request. This means you may lose more points on other problems if we discover grading errors in the other direction.
Legitimate regrade requests include:

The points were not added correctly.
The comments say I‚Äôm missing part (c), but it was actually on a different page.
The comments say that my algorithm is incorrect with this particular case, but I implemented my algorithm and it does work in that case.

Illegitimate regrade requests include:

I disagree with the rubric; I should have gotten more partial credit for my solution.
I understand that my solution wasn‚Äôt clear, but what I meant to say was correct.

title: Course Policy
text:
Grading Scheme

Collaboration Policy
You are encouraged to discuss problem sets with classmates, but you must write up your own solutions. Copying code or derivations is not allowed.


Resources

Textbook (Main): R Dorf and R Bishop, Modern Control System, Prentice-Hall, 13th Edition, 2017
Textbook (optional): Franklin, Powell, Emami-Naeini, Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems, (8th Ed).
Software: We will use Matlab/Simulink for computational assignments and and Python in some cases.

title: EE380: Control Systems
text:
NoteEE380 ‚Äî Control Systems



Spring 2026 ¬∑ Instructor: Dr.¬†Ali AlBeladi & Ali Mustafa
Build intuition and design skills for feedback control using real engineering examples.

title: EE380: Control Systems
text:
Start here
What to do before the first lecture - Read the Syllabus (grading, exam rules, late policy) - Check the Calendar for this week‚Äôs slides + topics - Bookmark the Homework page (all deadlines live there) - Install MATLAB/Simulink (recommended) and Python (optional for demos)






ImportantWhere to look for updates



This website is the single source of truth for announcements, schedule updates, and deadlines.

title: EE380: Control Systems
text:
Announcements


Week 2 ‚Äî HW1 is posted
Please check the Homework page for HW1 details and the due date/time.




Week 1 ‚Äî Getting started
Welcome to the course! Please review the Syllabus and install MATLAB/Simulink.
Python is optional unless you want to run local simulations.

title: Instructor Guide: EE380 Course Website
text:
This website is built with Quarto. It uses GitHub Pages for hosting and Pyodide for interactive Python simulations.





Create a new repository on GitHub (e.g., ee380-website).
Clone this folder to your machine.
Push this initial code to the main branch.





Install Quarto: Download from quarto.org.
VS Code: Recommended editor. Install the ‚ÄúQuarto‚Äù extension.
Install Pyodide Extension: Open a terminal in this folder and run: bash     quarto add quarto-ext/shinylive     # OR for standard pyodide     quarto add coatless-quarto/pyodide (Note: The current template assumes standard code blocks initially. To use the interactive features, you must install the extension.)








Open calendar.qmd.
Add new rows to the table for the upcoming week.
Link slides (put PDF files in a slides/ folder if you like, or link externally).





Open homework.qmd.
Add a new row to the table.
Link the PDF assignment.




To publish, you just need to push to GitHub. The Setup is already configured (see .github/workflows/publish.yml).
git add .
git commit -m "Update week 3 schedule"
git push
Within nearly 60 seconds, your site at https://<username>.github.io/<repo> will update.




Once the Pyodide extension is installed, you can add interactive cells like this:
```{pyodide-python}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
x = np.linspace(0, 10, 100)
plt.plot(x, np.sin(x))
plt.show()
```
This will render as an interactive, editable, regular Python cell in the student‚Äôs browser.
